title: Call Option Payoff at Expiration
equation_latex: \text{P} \times ay \times of \times f_{\text{C}} = m \times ax \times (S_{\text{T}} - \text{K}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

equation_latex: \text{P} \times ro \times fi \times t_{\text{C}} = m \times ax \times (S_{\text{T}} - \text{K}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

title: Put Option Profit at Expiration
equation_latex: \text{P} \times ro \times fi \times t_{\text{P}} = m \times ax \times (\text{K} - S_{\text{T}}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

title: Intrinsic Value (Call)
equation_latex: \text{I} \times V_{\text{C}} = m \times ax \times (S_{0} - \text{K}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Intrinsic Value (Put)
equation_latex: \text{I} \times V_{\text{P}} = m \times ax \times (\text{K} - S_{0}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Time Value
equation_latex: \text{T} \times \text{V} = O \times pt \times io \times n \text{P} \times ri \times ce - \text{I} \times nt \times ri \times ns \times ic \text{V} \times al \times ue
notes: This equation calculates the time value of an option. TV represents the time value This equation is fundamental to the time value of money concept, which states that money available at the present time is worth more than the same amount in the future due to its potential earning capacity. The mathematical formulation captures how capital compounds over time, forming the foundation for all discounted cash flow analysis.

title: Put-Call Parity
equation_latex: \text{C} + \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} = \text{P} + S_{0}
notes: This is the fundamental put-call parity relationship for European options on non-dividend paying stocks. C represents the call price

title: Put-Call Parity with Dividends
equation_latex: \text{C} + \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} = \text{P} + S_{0} * e^{-q \times \text{T}}
notes: This is the put-call parity for European options on dividend-paying stocks. The terms are the same as basic put-call parity

title: Lower Bound for European Call
equation_latex: \text{C} >= m \times ax \times (S_{0} - \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Lower Bound for European Put
equation_latex: \text{P} >= m \times ax \times (\text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} - S_{0}
notes: Equity Derivatives - Options Fundamentals

title: Upper Bound for European Call
equation_latex: \text{C} <= S_{0}
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European call option price. C represents the call price

title: Upper Bound for European Put
equation_latex: \text{P} <= \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}}
notes: This equation gives the upper bound for a European put option price. P represents the put price

title: American Call on Non-Dividend Stock
equation_latex: C_{A}m \times er \times ic \times an = C_{\text{E}}u \times ro \times pe \times an
notes: This equation states that for American calls on non-dividend paying stocks

title: American Put on Non-Dividend Stock
equation_latex: P_{A}m \times er \times ic \times an >= P_{\text{E}}u \times ro \times pe \times an
notes: This equation states that American puts can be worth more than European puts. P_American represents the American put price

title: Black-Scholes Call Formula
equation_latex: \text{C} = S_{0} * N \times (d_{1}) - \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{2})
notes: This is the famous Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European call option. C represents the call price

title: Black-Scholes Put Formula
equation_latex: \text{P} = \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (-d_{2}) - S_{0} * N \times (-d_{1})
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for pricing a European put option. P represents the put price

title: Black-Scholes d_1
equation_latex: d_{1} = (l \times n \times (S_{0}/\text{K}) + (r + s \times ig \times ma^{2}/2) * \text{T}) / (s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation defines the d_1 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_1 combines the moneyness of the option (ln(S_0/K))

title: Black-Scholes d_2
equation_latex: d_{2} = d_{1} - s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})
notes: This equation defines the d_2 parameter in the Black-Scholes formula. d_2 is simply d_1 minus sigma * sqrt(T). d_2 represents the probability that the option will be in the money at expiration under the risk-neutral measure.

title: Black-Scholes with Dividends
equation_latex: \text{C} = S_{0} * e^{-q \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{1}) - \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{2})
notes: This is the Black-Scholes formula for a European call on a dividend-paying stock. The stock price S_0 is discounted by the continuous dividend yield q using e^{-qT}. This adjustment accounts for the expected dividend payments during the option's life.

title: Black-Scholes d_1 with Dividends
equation_latex: d_{1} = (l \times n \times (S_{0}/\text{K}) + (r - q + s \times ig \times ma^{2}/2) * \text{T}) / (s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation defines d_1 for dividend-paying stocks. The dividend yield q is subtracted from r in the numerator

title: Delta (Call)
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta_{\text{C}} = N \times (d_{1})
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European call option. Delta_C represents the call delta Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

title: Delta (Put)
equation_latex: D \times el \times ta_{\text{P}} = N \times (d_{1}) - 1
notes: This equation calculates the delta of a European put option. Delta_P represents the put delta. For puts Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

title: Gamma
equation_latex: \text{G} \times am \times ma = N'(d_{1}) / (S_{0} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation calculates the gamma of a European option (same for calls and puts). Gamma represents the second derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. It measures the rate of change of delta and is highest for at-the-money options near expiration. Option pricing requires risk-neutral valuation frameworks that adjust expected returns for risk, typically using the risk-free rate rather than expected return under the physical measure. The Greeks measure sensitivity to various risk factors.

title: Normal PDF
equation_latex: N'(x) = (1/s \times qr \times t \times (2 * p \times i)) * e^{-x^{2}/2}
notes: This is the probability density function of the standard normal distribution. N'(x) represents the PDF value at x

title: Theta (Call)
equation_latex: \text{T} \times he \times ta_{\text{C}} = -(S_{0} * N'(d_{1}) * s \times ig \times ma) / (2 * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) - r * \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{2})
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European call option. Theta_C represents the call theta

title: Theta (Put)
equation_latex: \text{T} \times he \times ta_{\text{P}} = -(S_{0} * N'(d_{1}) * s \times ig \times ma) / (2 * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) + r * \text{K} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (-d_{2})
notes: This equation calculates the theta of a European put option. Theta_P represents the put theta. Unlike calls

title: Vega
equation_latex: \text{V} \times eg \times a = S_{0} * N'(d_{1}) * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})
notes: This equation calculates the vega of a European option (same for calls and puts). Vega represents the sensitivity of the option price to changes in volatility. Vega is always positive

title: Rho (Call)
equation_latex: R \times ho_{\text{C}} = \text{K} * \text{T} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (d_{2})
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European call option. Rho_C represents the call rho

title: Rho (Put)
equation_latex: R \times ho_{\text{P}} = -\text{K} * \text{T} * e^{-r \times \text{T}} * N \times (-d_{2})
notes: This equation calculates the rho of a European put option. Rho_P represents the put rho. For puts

title: Vanna
equation_latex: \text{V} \times an \times na = -N'(d_{1}) * d_{2} / s \times ig \times ma
notes: This equation calculates the vanna of a European option. Vanna represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in volatility

title: Charm
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ha \times rm = -N'(d_{1}) * (2 \times r \times \text{T} - d_{2} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) / (2 \times \text{T} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation calculates the charm of a European option. Charm represents the sensitivity of delta to changes in time (delta decay). Charm is important for understanding how delta changes as expiration approaches.

title: Vomma
equation_latex: \text{V} \times om \times ma = S_{0} * N'(d_{1}) * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}) * d_{1} * d_{2} / s \times ig \times ma
notes: This equation calculates the vomma (also called volga) of a European option. Vomma represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in volatility. Vomma is positive for most options

title: Veta
equation_latex: \text{V} \times et \times a = S_{0} * N'(d_{1}) * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}) * (r * q + (d_{1} * d_{2} * s \times ig \times ma) / (2 \times \text{T}))
notes: This equation calculates the veta of a European option. Veta represents the sensitivity of vega to changes in time (vega decay). Veta helps understand how volatility sensitivity changes as expiration approaches.

title: Speed
equation_latex: \text{S} \times pe \times ed = -N'(d_{1}) / (S_{0}^{2} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) * (1 + d_{1} / (s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})))
notes: This equation calculates the speed of a European option. Speed represents the third derivative of the option price with respect to the underlying price. Speed measures the rate of change of gamma and is important for understanding convexity risk.

title: Color
equation_latex: \text{C} \times ol \times or = -N'(d_{1}) / (2 * S_{0} * \text{T} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) * (1 + (2 \times r \times \text{T} - d_{2} * s \times ig \times ma * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T})) / (2 \times \text{T}))
notes: This equation calculates the color of a European option. Color represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in time (gamma decay). Color helps understand how the curvature of the option price changes as expiration approaches.

title: Zomma
equation_latex: Z \times om \times ma = N'(d_{1}) * (d_{1} * d_{2} - 1) / (S_{0} * s \times ig \times ma^{2} * s \times qr \times t \times (\text{T}))
notes: This equation calculates the zomma of a European option. Zomma represents the sensitivity of gamma to changes in volatility. Zomma is important for managing volatility risk in gamma-sensitive portfolios.

title: Implied Volatility (Definition)

title: Martingale Property
